nodes.text: Main console: LOAD-SHED RESPONSE overlay, pinned atop shutdown verification UI. (pause) Yellow banner persists: DEMAND EVENT ACTIVE — RESPONSE REQUIRED. (pause) Under it, almost offended: VERIFICATION MODE: STABILITY REQUIRED.

Control Room. Utility Dispatch. (pause) Timestamp 14:22:04. (pause) Confirm you're acting on the demand event. (pause) I need your action record ID. (pause) Send it when you have it. (pause) Also—state you will maintain stability. (pause) Stated. Not assumed.

Don’t say “emergency”. (pause) Don’t say “we’ll try.” (pause) Say: “acknowledge the demand event.” (pause) Say: “initiating response.” (pause) Say: “stability maintained per interlocks.” (pause) Keep it ugly for the transcript.
The console shows big, friendly buttons—liability: VIEW/LOAD MAP. PRINT ACTION-HEADER. CONFIGURE SHED. EXECUTE ROUTING.

choices.text: look: View load map and current critical/noncritical tags.
ask: What does “maintain stability” mean in this console?
use: Configure shed (staged vs single-step).
use: Print action header to the log tray.
persuade: Use OLEA standard wording (authorized signatory).
threaten: Cite the stability clause and request immediate escalation handling.
leave: Step away from the console.

nodes.text: Acknowledging demand event. Initiating load-shed response. Stability maintained per interlocks. Action record ID pending console header.
Accepted. (pause) Timestamp 14:22:11. (pause) Provide the record ID when available. (pause) Report shed start time when first action occurs.

Good. Keep it standard. (pause)
Now get the console to output (pause)
something attributable.
Under the stability clause, I need escalation handling and a logged directive. Confirm you want the shed executed now, attributable and stable.
Noted. Timestamp 14:22:14. (pause) Directive stands. Execute shed now. (pause) Avoid cycling and step-load chatter. (pause) Provide record ID. (pause) Provide shed start time.
Okay. (pause) Don’t push it further. (pause) Confirm action, then print. (pause) Something we can staple.
Escalate this. I’m not acting on an undocumented directive.
Negative. (pause) Timestamp 14:22:16. (pause) Directive is documented via recording and log mirror. (pause) Confirm action now. (pause) Do not delay shed for process language.
Yeah, it’s recorded. (pause) Still need that header. (pause) Print it. Then act. (pause) Don’t burn time on tone.

The screen redraws into a block diagram: feeder names and breaker groups. (pause) Three load categories appear with mismatched fonts. (pause) CRITICAL lists chamber environmental and rotation frame lubrication. (pause) It also shows a box labeled VERIFICATION SUPPORT—unhelpfully most of the building.
VERIFICATION SUPPORT. Great. (pause) Checklist wants a stable baseline. (pause) It treats it as untouchable. (pause) Dispatch sees it as discretionary. (pause) Pick your courtroom.

choices.text: ask: How much can I shed without touching “verification support”?
look: Inspect breaker group details (restart surge notes).
leave: Back to the console menu.

nodes.text: How much shed without touching verification support?
Three shed presets highlight. None meet the target alone.

We can shed a little (pause) without touching it. (pause) Twelve megawatts won't happen that way. (pause) To hit target clean, (pause) we reclass support—or (pause) we drop something that auto-recovers (pause) and Dispatch calls it a miss.

Several groups carry a warning: AUTO-RECOVER ENABLED. (pause) RESTART SURGE LIKELY. (pause)
A few are annotated in terse maintenance shorthand: “CHATTER RISK.” (pause) “THERMAL LAG.” (pause) “DO NOT CYCLE.”
And to be clear. (pause) “Auto-recovers” is not a shed. (pause) It is a delay. (pause) Avoid cycling. (pause) Avoid chatter. (pause) Give me something stable. (pause) Give me something attributable.
Define “maintain stability” in this console.

Stability means your node doesn't create a problem. (pause) I don't have to name. (pause) Voltage in band. (pause) No step-load chatter. (pause) No cycling. (pause) And—because it comes up—no undocumented behavior. (pause) That's not technical. (pause) That's legal.
Undocumented. (pause) That's the word that matters. (pause) We can stage it with timestamps, (pause) or single-step it. (pause) The no-chatter macro is the one (pause) the checklist won't like.

choices.text: use: Configure a staged shed plan.
use: Configure a single-step shed.
leave: Back to the console menu.

nodes.text: A configuration pane opens: TARGET SHED 12 MW. (pause) Slider disabled. Presets only. (pause) Tabs: STAGED and SINGLE-STEP. (pause) Cursor blinks, like it wants a signature.
Staged buys you more timestamps. (pause) Single-step's cleaner electrically—and whoever signs it, wears it.

choices.text: use: Select STAGED shed (multiple groups).
use: Select SINGLE-STEP shed (one macro).
leave: Back to the console menu.

nodes.text: The console assembles three staged groups. The third is marked: VERIFICATION SUPPORT — TEMPORARY RECLASS REQUIRED.
There it is. TEMPORARY RECLASS REQUIRED. (pause) Use an existing code. (pause) Don’t invent a category under pressure.
Confirm you’re acting. (pause) I don’t need your philosophy. (pause) I need a time stamp. (pause) And a stable response.

choices.text: talk: Confirmed. Initiating staged shed.
use: Reclass “verification support” as noncritical (temporary).
leave: Back to the console menu.

nodes.text: Confirmed. Initiating staged shed.
Timestamp 14:22:31. Logged. (pause) Provide action record ID when available. (pause) Report first step time when it occurs.
Good. Make the reclass airtight. (pause) Or they write "cycling" on you.

A dialog box appears with a legal tone and a petty request: SELECT JUSTIFICATION CODE. (pause)
The available codes are pre-filled. None are kind.
Pick a code that already exists. (pause) Don’t write a new justification. (pause) That’s a meeting you’ll lose.

choices.text: use: Justification: GRID DIRECTIVE — DEMAND EVENT.
leave: Back to staged options.

nodes.text: VERIFICATION SUPPORT flips from CRITICAL to NONCRITICAL with no animation, like it’s ashamed.
Good. (pause) Put classification update in the notes. (pause) That wording is what survives.
The console offers one macro: EXECUTE ROUTING: ALIGNMENT-SEQUENCE LOAD ROUTING (12 MW CLEAN). (pause) Beneath it: NOTE: MAY ALTER VERIFICATION BASELINE. (pause) The word “may” is doing too much work.
That’s the one. (pause) Keeps the interlocks happy. (pause) Tightens up the rotation frames. (pause) Checklist will gripe about “baseline.” (pause) We just keep it documented.

choices.text: ask: Why does it say “alignment-sequence”?
use: Execute alignment-sequence load routing.
leave: Back to the console menu.

nodes.text: Why “alignment-sequence”?
Because Legal didn’t want anyone describing it. (pause) In detail. (pause) Operationally: it balances load. (pause) Without chatter, it coordinates the frames. (pause) That’s all we say.
Execute.

The console asks for final confirmation in all caps, like volume is authority. (pause)
ACKNOWLEDGE: ROUTING WILL INITIATE AUTOMATED ALIGNMENT CONTROL. (pause)
The confirm button is labeled: I ACKNOWLEDGE.

choices.text: talk: I acknowledge.
leave: Cancel and step back.

nodes.text: You back out. The macro remains highlighted, waiting like it knows you’ll return.
Timestamp 14:22:57. Confirm you're acting. (pause) Confirm you'll maintain stability.
Say it clean. Then watch the numbers.
Acting. Stability maintained per interlocks.
The console logs a new line item: ALIGNMENT CONTROL: ARMED. ROUTING: IN PROGRESS. (pause) In the corner, the small chamber camera feed stutters.

The containment sphere’s surface flickers—matte to reflective, reflective to matte—like a thought it mustn’t have. (pause)
The console continues counting down routing steps as if nothing visual is relevant.
Armed is a lousy word. (pause) But it’s what the panel prints. (pause) We gave it permission, that’s all.
The log printer wakes with a reluctant whine. (pause) A strip curls into the tray. (pause) ACTION HEADER — CONTROL ROOM CONSOLE, serial and timestamp.
Good. Serial and timestamp—that’s attribution. (pause) It stays tied to the console record. (pause) Right where it belongs.

choices.text: show: Read back the header serial to Dispatch.
leave: Back to the console menu.

nodes.text: Action header serial CR-CON-0194.
Received. Timestamp 14:22:19. (pause) Proceed. (pause) Report shed start time. (pause) When the first action occurs.
You step back. The demand banner stays pinned, politely escalating at the edge of your vision.
Walk off if you need to breathe. (pause) Timestamp still runs. (pause) Come back. (pause) Do it with something we can staple.

choices.text: leave: Return to the main console.
leave: Go to another hotspot.
